ocr.line: adjici ut lectores integrioris formae admoneantur. Μὴ θελήσας
ocr.sentence: adjici ut lectores integrioris formae admoneantur.
ocr.region: adjici ut lectores integrioris formae admoneantur. Mr θελήσας Isaeus Cir. p.69. $.11. zu} θέλοι Lycurg. Leoer. p. 157, 77. etc. et similia apud Demosthenem, cui Schaeferus μὴ ἐθέλειν eximere studet ad p. 1451, 61. cf. Ruediger ad Philipp. I. p. 27. Thuoydidi familiarius verbum trisyllabum , nee dubita- tione caruit ei θέλοιμεν VI. 34, A. sed Platoni jure reli- quit Schneiderus ad Civ. T. I. p. 230. T. III. p. 15%. etsi apud hunc ut apud ceteros antiquiores praevalet ἐθέλειν. V. 25. Ἐφθαρμένας — Hunc et insequentem versum producit Suidas s. Asius. Verbum κατηναρισμένας ex h. l. idem et Ilesychius et Schol. Ven. XXI. 26. enotarunt. Quod sequitur, ποιμνίων ἐπιστάταις, id Suidas s. Ἐπιστάτις in- terpretatur zeig «vol, fortasse ne Ajax caedis verae nec ad vindictam necessariae reus agatur; idemque sensisse videtur gui v. 232. adseripsit: οὗτοι γὰρ ἐνόμιζον καὶ ποιμένας αὐτὸν ἀνῃρηκέναι, id est, solam in hoc conjeciuram sequun- tur. _Rectius Schol. Rom. zoig ποιμέσι· καλῶς δὲ τοῦτο, iva μὴ παραγένοιτό τις ἀπαγγέλλων To σαφές. Sic ποιμ- νίων ἐπιστάταις Plat. Legg. X. 906. A. V. 28. Αἰτίαν νέμει. Codd. A. La. Lb. Aug. B. τρέπει, hic supra seripto νέμει. IIlud Valckenarius ad Hipp. p- 306. e,glossa eis αὐτὸν τρέπει ortum putat. Galenus de Plenit. c. XI. 346. T. VII. Chart. p. 582. Kuehn. οὐκ ἴσην ἅπασι νέμει τὴν alviav. V. 29. Keil μοί τις ὀπτήρ- εἰσιδών — haec verba ap- ponit Thomas s. Orryje, lolum versum cum insequenti Suidas s. Ὀπτῆρας, quam vocem Eustathius p. 788, 31. ex h. |. affert. Ep. Pr. V. 30. Πηδῶντα nedie. E Scholiastae interpreta- mento τῷ πεδίῳ nata est codd. nonnullorum lectio πεδίῳ. Syntaxis hujus exempla abunde multa extant, sed regula parum claret; πλανηθῆναι τὴν ἐρήμην lesai. XVI. 8. πολ- λὴν ἐρημίαν Conon. Narr. II. πολλὴν γῆν Xenoph. Eph. V. 14, 116. Plutarch. Lucull. e. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾷσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν ἀπίαν ἀλώμενος Oed. C. 1686: τὴν πλανοστιβῆ γῆν Beßus Aesch. Eum. 76.

groundtruth.region: adjici ut lectores integrioris formae admoneantur. Μὴ θελήσας lsaeus Cir. p. 69. §. 11. μὴ θέλοι Lycurg. Leocr. p. 157, 77. etc. et similia apud Demosthenem, cui Schaeferus μὴ ἐθέλειν eximere studet ad p. 1451, 61. cf. Ruediger ad Philipp. I. p. 27. Thucydidi familiarius verbum trisyllabum, nec dubita- tione caruit εἰ θέλοιμεν Vl. 34, ⟨. sed Platoni jure reli- quit Schneiderus ad Civ. T. I. p. 230. T. III. p. 154. etsi apud hunc ut apud ceteros antiquiores praevalet ἐθέλειν. V. 25. Ἐφθαρμένας - Hunc et insequentem versum producit Suidas s. Λείας. Verbum κατηναρισμένας ex h. l. idem et Hesychius et Schol. Ven. XXI. 26. enotarunt. Quod sequitur, ποιμνίων ἐπιστάταις, id Suidas s. Ἐπιστάτις in- terpretatur τοῖς κυσί, fortasse ne Ajax caedis verae nec ad vindictam necessariae reus agatur ; idemque sensisse videtur qui v. 232. adscripsit : οὗτοι γὰρ ἐνόμιζον καὶ ποιμένας αὐτὸν ἀνῃρηκέναι, id est, solam in hoc conjecturam sequun- tur. Rectius Schol. Rom. τοῖς ποιμέσι· καλῶς δὲ τοῦτο, ἵνα μὴ παραγένοιτό τις ἀπαγγέλλων τὸ σαφές. Sic ποιμ- νίων ἐπιστάταις Plat. Legg. X. 906. A. V. 28. Αἰτίαν νέμει. Codd. Δ. La. Lb. Aug. B. τρέπει, hic supra scripto νέμει. Illud Valckenarius ad Hipp. p. 306. e glossa εἰς αὐτὸν τρέπει ortum putat. Galenus de Plenit. c. Xl. 346. T. VII. Chart. p. 582. Kuehn. οὐκ ἴσην ἅπασι νέμει τὴν αἰτίαν. V. 29. Καί μοί τις ὀπτήρ - εἰςιδών - haec verba ap- ponit Thomas s. Ὀπτήρ, totum versum cum insequenti Suidas s. Ὀπτῆρας, quam vocem Eustathius p. 788, 31. ex h. l. affert. ED. PR. V. 30 Πηδῶντα πεδία. E Scholiastae interpreta- mento τῷ πεδίῳ nata est codd. nonnullorum lectio πεδίῳ. Syntaxis hujus exempla abunde multa extant, sed regula parum claret ; πλανηθῆναι τὴν ἐρήμην Iesai. XVI. 8. πολ- λήν ἐρημίαν Conon. Narr. II. πολλὴν γῆν Xenoph. Eph. V. 14, 116. Plutarch. Lucull. c. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾶσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν ἀπίαν ἀλώμενος 0ed. C. 1686. τὴν πλανοστιβῆ γῆν βεβώς Aesch, Eum. 76.

A:

My answer is not a complete solution, but you can give a rough answer with the following rules of thumb:

Change words in quotes (single quotes ') or double quotes ") to a single quote.

Rom. zoig ποιμέσι· καλῶς δὲ τοῦτο, iva μὴ παραγένοιτό τις ἀπαγγέλλων To σαφές. Sic ποιμ- νίων ἐπιστάταις Plat. Legg. X. 906. A. V. 28. Αἰτίαν νέμει. Codd. A. La. Lb. Aug. B. τρέπει, hic supra seripto νέμει. IIlud Valckenarius ad Hipp. p- 306. e,glossa eis αὐτὸν τρέπει ortum putat. Galenus de Plenit. c. XI. 346. T. VII. Chart. p. 582. Kuehn. οὐκ ἴσην ἅπασι νέμει τὴν alviav. V. 29. Keil μοί τις ὀπτήρ- εἰσιδών — haec verba ap- ponit Thomas s. Orryje, lolum versum cum insequenti Suidas s. Ὀπτῆρας, quam vocem Eustathius p. 788, 31. ex h. |. affert. Ep. Pr. V. 30. Πηδῶντα nedie. E Scholiastae interpreta- mento τῷ πεδίῳ nata est codd. nonnullorum lectio πεδίῳ. Syntaxis hujus exempla abunde multa extant, sed regula parum claret; πλανηθῆναι τὴν ἐρήμην lesai. XVI. 8. πολ- λὴν ἐρημίαν Conon. Narr. II. πολλὴν γῆν Xenoph. Eph. V. 14, 116. Plutarch. Lucull. e. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾷσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν ἀπίαν ἀλώμενος Oed. C. 1686: τὴν πλανοστιβῆ γῆν Beßus Aesch. Eum. 76.

Hel. 1094. ἠρύσει δὲ τὸ μὴ πρὸς τὴν πλανηθῆν ἀνθρώπου τὴν μὲν δύο, ἀνθρώπῳ ἀπὸ ἑτέρων, ἀνεκάλεων, ἀνεγράφων τῆς μὲν κόσμης, τοῦτό ἐστιν τὸ μὴ ἀπὸ μνήμης. πᾶσαν πλεῖστον τοῦ παράπειρος Eur. Hel. 1094. τὸ δὲ πλῆθος μὴ πρὸς τοῦ παράπειρος ἕτερον γὰρ πλῆθος ποι- mέως ἐπίστευσε, id est, πλὴν ἀνάρχεως ὁρᾶται, πλῆθος ἀπὸ ἑτέρων, ἀνεκάλεων, ἀνεγράφων τῆς ἐν τῷ κόσμῳ πλῆθος. ἀπὸ τοῦ μνήμου Eur. Hel. 1097. ἦρξα δὲ τῆς πλανηθῆς ὡς ἀπὸ τῆς ἐξ ἀνθρώπων κόσμου ἕτερα γῆς Eur. Hel. 1100. πλὴν ἑνῆς γῆς Eur. Hel. 1101. πάθη μὲν οὖν τὴν πλανηθῆν γῆν ἑτέρων ἔργων, ἐπὶ τῆς δὲ μνήμης Eur. Hel. 1111. ὡς γὰρ πλανηθῆναι ἀνάρχεια, ὡς μύθη καὶ οὐκ οἶσθον τὴν ἡσυχῆν πνεῦμα οὐδὲ τὴν ἐν τῇ ἐξ αὐτῶν πνευμάτων ἀκούσασιν Eur. Hel. 1135. πλῆθος ἥρᾶτο ἥρᾶτο πλανηθῆναι Eur. Hel. 1146. πλανηθῆναι γὰρ ἐστὶ ἡ ἀρχὴ ἡ ἁπάντη Eur. Hel. 1152. πλανηθῆναι γὰρ ἡ συνέβη Eur. Hel. 1156. οὐκ εἶχεν ὁ δὲ μῆθος πλανηθῆναι Eur. Hel. 1163. ἕτερον γὰρ πλὴν ἑτέρον πλάνηθεν Eur. Hel. 1183. πᾶσαν πολύπλανος Eur. Hel. 1187. πολύπλατος Eur. Hel. 1188. πλῆθος πολύπλατος Eur. Hel. 1189. πολύπλατος Eur. Hel. 1191. πολύπλατος Eur. Hel. 1192. πολύπλατος Eur. Hel. 1195. τὸ δὲ πλῆθος πολύπλανος Eur. Hel. 1196. πλῆθος πολύπλανος Eur. Hel. 1197. πλῆθος πολύπλανος Eur. Hel. 1198. πολύ

ocr.region: adjici ut lectores integrioris formae admoneantur. Mr θελήσας Isaeus Cir. p.69. $.11. zu} θέλοι Lycurg. Leoer. p. 157, 77. etc. et similia apud Demosthenem, cui Schaeferus μὴ ἐθέλειν eximere studet ad p. 1451, 61. cf. Ruediger ad Philipp. I. p. 27. Thuoydidi familiarius verbum trisyllabum , nee dubita- tione caruit ei θέλοιμεν VI. 34, A. sed Platoni jure reli- quit Schneiderus ad Civ. T. I. p. 230. T. III. p. 15%. etsi apud hunc ut apud ceteros antiquiores praevalet ἐθέλειν. V. 25. Ἐφθαρμένας — Hunc et insequentem versum producit Suidas s. Asius. Verbum κατηναρισμένας ex h. l. idem et Ilesychius et Schol. Ven. XXI. 26. enotarunt. Quod sequitur, ποιμνίων ἐπιστάταις, id Suidas s. Ἐπιστάτις in- terpretatur zeig «vol, fortasse ne Ajax caedis verae nec ad vindictam necessariae reus agatur; idemque sensisse videtur gui v. 232. adseripsit: οὗτοι γὰρ ἐνόμιζον καὶ ποιμένας αὐτὸν ἀνῃρηκέναι, id est, solam in hoc conjeciuram sequun- tur. _Rectius Schol. Rom. zoig ποιμέσι· καλῶς δὲ τοῦτο, iva μὴ παραγένοιτό τις ἀπαγγέλλων To σαφές. Sic ποιμ- νίων ἐπιστάταις Plat. Legg. X. 906. A. V. 28. Αἰτίαν νέμει. Codd. A. La. Lb. Aug. B. τρέπει, hic supra seripto νέμει. IIlud Valckenarius ad Hipp. p- 306. e,glossa eis αὐτὸν τρέπει ortum putat. Galenus de Plenit. c. XI. 346. T. VII. Chart. p. 582. Kuehn. οὐκ ἴσην ἅπασι νέμει τὴν alviav. V. 29. Keil μοί τις ὀπτήρ- εἰσιδών — haec verba ap- ponit Thomas s. Orryje, lolum versum cum insequenti Suidas s. Ὀπτῆρας, quam vocem Eustathius p. 788, 31. ex h. |. affert. Ep. Pr. V. 30. Πηδῶντα nedie. E Scholiastae interpreta- mento τῷ πεδίῳ nata est codd. nonnullorum lectio πεδίῳ. Syntaxis hujus exempla abunde multa extant, sed regula parum claret; πλανηθῆναι τὴν ἐρήμην lesai. XVI. 8. πολ- λὴν ἐρημίαν Conon. Narr. II. πολλὴν γῆν Xenoph. Eph. V. 14, 116. Plutarch. Lucull. e. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾷσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν ἀπίαν ἀλώμενος Oed. C. 1686: τὴν πλανοστιβῆ γῆν Beßus Aesch. Eum. 76.

Hel. 1097. ἦρξα δὲ τῆς πλανηθῆς ὡς ἀπὸ τῆς ἐξ ἀνθρώπων κόσμου ἕτερα γῆς Eur. Hel. 1100. πλὴν ἑνῆς γῆς Eur. Hel. 1101. πάθη μὲν οὖν τὴν πλανηθῆν γῆν ἑτέρων ἔργων, ἐπὶ τῆς δὲ μνήμης Eur. ocr.line: quit Schneiderus ad Civ. T. I. p. 230. T. III. p. 154. etsi
ocr.region: adjici ut lectores integrioris formae admoneantur. Mr θελήσας Isaeus Cir. p.69. $.11. zu} θέλοι Lycurg. Leoer. p. 157, 77. etc. et similia apud Demosthenem, cui Schaeferus μὴ ἐθέλειν eximere studet ad p. 1451, 61. cf. Ruediger ad Philipp. I. p. 27. Thuoydidi familiarius verbum trisyllabum , nee dubita- tione caruit ei θέλοιμεν VI. 34, A. sed Platoni jure reli- quit Schneiderus ad Civ. T. I. p. 230. T. III. p. 15%. etsi apud hunc ut apud ceteros antiquiores praevalet ἐθέλειν. V. 25. Ἐφθαρμένας — Hunc et insequentem versum producit Suidas s. Asius. Verbum κατηναρισμένας ex h. l. idem et Ilesychius et Schol. Ven. XXI. 26. enotarunt. Quod sequitur, ποιμνίων ἐπιστάταις, id Suidas s. Ἐπιστάτις in- terpretatur zeig «vol, fortasse ne Ajax caedis verae nec ad vindictam necessariae reus agatur; idemque sensisse videtur gui v. 232. adseripsit: οὗτοι γὰρ ἐνόμιζον καὶ ποιμένας αὐτὸν ἀνῃρηκέναι, id est, solam in hoc conjeciuram sequun- tur. _Rectius Schol. Rom. zoig ποιμέσι· καλῶς δὲ τοῦτο, iva μὴ παραγένοιτό τις ἀπαγγέλλων To σαφές. Sic ποιμ- νίων ἐπιστάταις Plat. Legg. X. 906. A. V. 28. Αἰτίαν νέμει. Codd. A. La. Lb. Aug. B. τρέπει, hic supra seripto νέμει. IIlud Valckenarius ad Hipp. p- 306. e,glossa eis αὐτὸν τρέπει ortum putat. Galenus de Plenit. c. XI. 346. T. VII. Chart. p. 582. Kuehn. οὐκ ἴσην ἅπασι νέμει τὴν alviav. V. 29. Keil μοί τις ὀπτήρ- εἰσιδών — haec verba ap- ponit Thomas s. Orryje, lolum versum cum insequenti Suidas s. Ὀπτῆρας, quam vocem Eustathius p. 788, 31. ex h. |. affert. Ep. Pr. V. 30. Πηδῶντα nedie. E Scholiastae interpreta- mento τῷ πεδίῳ nata est codd. nonnullorum lectio πεδίῳ. Syntaxis hujus exempla abunde multa extant, sed regula parum claret; πλανηθῆναι τὴν ἐρήμην lesai. XVI. 8. πολ- λὴν ἐρημίαν Conon. Narr. II. πολλὴν γῆν Xenoph. Eph. V. 14, 116. Plutarch. Lucull. e. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾷσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν ἀπίαν ἀλώμενος Oed. C. 1686: τὴν πλανοστιβῆ γῆν Beßus Aesch. Eum. 76.

Hel. 1094. τὸ δὲ πλῆθος μὴ πρὸς τοῦ παράπειρος ἕτερον γὰρ πλῆθος ποι- mέως ἐπίστευσε, id est, πλὴν ἀνάρχεως ὁρᾶται, πλῆθος ἀπὸ ἑτέρων, ἀνεκάλεων, ἀνεγράφων τῆς ἐν τῷ κόσμῳ πλῆθος. ἀπὸ τοῦ μνήμου Eur. Ἐπιστάτις in- terpretatur τοῖς κυσί, fortasse ne Ajax caedis verae nec ad vindictam necessariae reus agatur ; idemque sensisse videtur qui v. 232. adscripsit : οὗτοι γὰρ ἐνόμιζον καὶ ποιμένας αὐτὸν ἀνῃρηκέναι, id est, solam in hoc conjecturam sequun- tur. Rectius Schol. Rom. τοῖς ποιμέσι· καλῶς δὲ τοῦτο, ἵνα μὴ παραγένοιτό τις ἀπαγγέλλων τὸ σαφές. Sic ποιμ- νίων ἐπιστάταις Plat. Legg. X. 906. A. V. 28. Αἰτίαν νέμει. Codd. Δ. La. Lb. Aug. Ὀπτῆρας, quam vocem Eustathius p. 788, 31. ex h. l. affert. ED. PR. V. 30 Πηδῶντα πεδία. E Scholiastae interpreta- mento τῷ πεδίῳ nata est codd. nonnullorum lectio πεδίῳ. Syntaxis hujus exempla abunde multa extant, sed regula parum claret ; πλανηθῆναι τὴν ἐρήμην Iesai. XVI. 8. πολ- λήν ἐρημίαν Conon. Narr. II. πολλὴν γῆν Xenoph. Eph. V. 14, 116. Plutarch. Lucull. c. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾶσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν ἀπίαν ἀλώμενος 0ed. C. 1686. τὴν πλανοστιβῆ γῆν βεβώς Aesch, Eum. 76.

Hel. 1183. πᾶσαν πολύπλανος Eur. Hel. 1187. πολύπλατος Eur. Hel. 1188. πλῆθος πολύπλατος Eur. Hel. 1189. πολύπλατος Eur. Hel. 1191. πολύπλατος Eur. Hel. 1192. πολύπλατος Eur. ocr.line: tur. Rectius Schol. Rom. τοῖς ποιμέσι· καλῶς δὲ τοῦτο,
ocr.region: adjici ut lectores integrioris formae admoneantur. Mr θελήσας Isaeus Cir. p.69. $.11. zu} θέλοι Lycurg. Leoer. p. 157, 77. etc. et similia apud Demosthenem, cui Schaeferus μὴ ἐθέλειν eximere studet ad p. 1451, 61. cf. Ruediger ad Philipp. I. p. 27. Thuoydidi familiarius verbum trisyllabum , nee dubita- tione caruit ei θέλοιμεν VI. 34, A. sed Platoni jure reli- quit Schneiderus ad Civ. T. I. p. 230. T. III. p. 15%. etsi apud hunc ut apud ceteros antiquiores praevalet ἐθέλειν. V. 25. Ἐφθαρμένας — Hunc et insequentem versum producit Suidas s. Asius. Verbum κατηναρισμένας ex h. l. idem et Ilesychius et Schol. Ven. XXI. 26. enotarunt. Quod sequitur, ποιμνίων ἐπιστάταις, id Suidas s. Ἐπιστάτις in- terpretatur zeig «vol, fortasse ne Ajax caedis verae nec ad vindictam necessariae reus agatur; idemque sensisse videtur gui v. 232. adseripsit: οὗτοι γὰρ ἐνόμιζον καὶ ποιμένας αὐτὸν ἀνῃρηκέναι, id est, solam in hoc conjeciuram sequun- tur. _Rectius Schol. Rom. zoig ποιμέσι· καλῶς δὲ τοῦτο, iva μὴ παραγένοιτό τις ἀπαγγέλλων To σαφές. Sic ποιμ- νίων ἐπιστάταις Plat. Legg. X. 906. A. V. 28. Αἰτίαν νέμει. Codd. A. La. Lb. Aug. B. τρέπει, hic supra seripto νέμει. IIlud Valckenarius ad Hipp. p- 306. e,glossa eis αὐτὸν τρέπει ortum putat. Galenus de Plenit. c. XI. 346. T. VII. Chart. p. 582. Kuehn. οὐκ ἴσην ἅπασι νέμει τὴν alviav. V. 29. Keil μοί τις ὀπτήρ- εἰσιδών — haec verba ap- ponit Thomas s. Orryje, lolum versum cum insequenti Suidas s. Ὀπτῆρας, quam vocem Eustathius p. 788, 31. ex h. |. affert. Ep. Pr. V. 30. Πηδῶντα nedie. E Scholiastae interpreta- mento τῷ πεδίῳ nata est codd. nonnullorum lectio πεδίῳ. Syntaxis hujus exempla abunde multa extant, sed regula parum claret; πλανηθῆναι τὴν ἐρήμην lesai. XVI. 8. πολ- λὴν ἐρημίαν Conon. Narr. II. πολλὴν γῆν Xenoph. Eph. V. 14, 116. Plutarch. Lucull. e. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾷσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν ἀπίαν ἀλώμενος Oed. C. 1686: τὴν πλανοστιβῆ γῆν Beßus Aesch. Eum. 76.

prediction.sentence:
Légg.

My task is to do a simple spell-check in a document. Here is an example of a problem:
The text below contains both words with e's and e's with s's:

The e's in these words have an accent but the e's with s's do not. Can you suggest a way to correct the text? I only want to remove the e's with s's.
e - as in "ear"

I - as in "I"

e's
s's
e's with s's

If you can suggest a solution that also works for other pairs of words with different e's and s's, that would be helpful.
You should write your answer as a single file

Ὀπτῆρας, quam vocem Eustathius p. 788, 31. ex h. |. affert. Ep. Pr. V. 30. Πηδῶντα nedie. E Scholiastae interpreta- mento τῷ πεδίῳ nata est codd. nonnullorum lectio πεδίῳ. Syntaxis hujus exempla abunde multa extant, sed regula parum claret; πλανηθῆναι τὴν ἐρήμην lesai. XVI. 8. πολ- λὴν ἐρημίαν Conon. Narr. II. πολλὴν γῆν Xenoph. Eph. V. 14, 116. Plutarch. Lucull. e. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾷσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν χθόνα πλανηθεῖν Eur. Hel. 728. κόμμηθε τῆς πλανηθῆς τὸν οἰκήτην Eur. Hel. 1057. δυσπόρηθεν ἐκ πανοίης πλάνηθεν Eur. Hel. 1061. πλανηθῆναι πολὺν ἔργων Eur. Hel. 1083. οὐκ ἐστὶ δὲ ἔστιν τὸν ἄνευ τῆς πλανηθῆς οὐδὲ πλεῖστον τοῦ παράπειρος Eur. Hel. 1092. οὐδὲν δὲ ἔστι τὸ πλῆθος τῆς πλανηθῆς Eur. Hel. 1094. ἠρύσει δὲ τὸ μὴ πρὸς τὴν πλανηθῆν ἀνθρώπου τὴν μὲν δύο, ἀνθρώπῳ ἀπὸ ἑτέρων, ἀνεκάλεων, ἀνεγράφων τῆς μὲν κόσμης, τοῦτό ἐστιν τὸ μὴ ἀπὸ μνήμης. πᾶσαν πλεῖστον τοῦ παράπειρος Eur. Hel. 1094. τὸ δὲ πλῆθος μὴ πρὸς τοῦ παράπειρος ἕτερον γὰρ πλῆθος ποι- mέως ἐπίστευσε, id est, πλὴν ἀνάρχεως ὁρᾶται, πλῆθος ἀπὸ ἑτέρων, ἀνεκάλεων, ἀνεγράφων τῆς ἐν τῷ κόσμῳ πλῆθος. ἀπὸ τοῦ μνήμου Eur. Hel. 1097. ἦρξα δὲ τῆς πλανηθῆς ὡς ἀπὸ τῆς ἐξ ἀνθρώπων κόσμου ἕτερα γῆς Eur. Hel. 1100. πλὴν ἑνῆς γῆς Eur. Hel. 1101. πάθη μὲν οὖν τὴν πλανηθῆν γῆν ἑτέρων ἔργων, ἐπὶ τῆς δὲ μνήμης Eur. Hel. 1111. ὡς γὰρ πλανηθῆναι ἀνάρχεια, ὡς μύθη καὶ οὐκ οἶσθον τὴν ἡσυχῆν πνεῦμα οὐδὲ τὴν ἐν τῇ ἐξ αὐτῶν πνευμάτων ἀκούσασιν Eur. Hel. 1135. πλῆθος ἥρᾶτο ἥρᾶτο πλανηθῆναι Eur. Hel. 1146. πλανηθῆναι γὰρ ἐστὶ ἡ ἀρχὴ ἡ ἁπάντη Eur. Hel. 1152. πλανηθῆναι γὰρ ἡ συνέβη Eur. Hel. 1156. οὐκ εἶχεν ὁ δὲ μῆθος πλανηθῆναι Eur. Hel. 1163. ἕτερον γὰρ πλὴν ἑτέρον πλάνηθεν Eur. Hel. 1183. πᾶσαν πολύπλανος Eur. Hel. 1187. πολύπλατος Eur. Hel. 1188. πλῆθος πολύπλατος Eur. Hel. 1189. πολύπλατος Eur. Hel. 1191. πολύπλατος Eur. Hel. 1192. πολύπλατος Eur. ocr.line: νίων ἐπιστάταις Plat. Legg. X. 906. A.
ocr.region: adjici ut lectores integrioris formae admoneantur. Mr θελήσας Isaeus Cir. p.69. $.11. zu} θέλοι Lycurg. Leoer. p. 157, 77. etc. et similia apud Demosthenem, cui Schaeferus μὴ ἐθέλειν eximere studet ad p. 1451, 61. cf. Ruediger ad Philipp. I. p. 27. Thuoydidi familiarius verbum trisyllabum , nee dubita- tione caruit ei θέλοιμεν VI. 34, A. sed Platoni jure reli- quit Schneiderus ad Civ. T. I. p. 230. T. III. p. 15%. etsi apud hunc ut apud ceteros antiquiores praevalet ἐθέλειν. V. 25. Ἐφθαρμένας — Hunc et insequentem versum producit Suidas s. Asius. Verbum κατηναρισμένας ex h. l. idem et Ilesychius et Schol. Ven. XXI. 26. enotarunt. Quod sequitur, ποιμνίων ἐπιστάταις, id Suidas s. Ἐπιστάτις in- terpretatur zeig «vol, fortasse ne Ajax caedis verae nec ad vindictam necessariae reus agatur; idemque sensisse videtur gui v. 232. adseripsit: οὗτοι γὰρ ἐνόμιζον καὶ ποιμένας αὐτὸν ἀνῃρηκέναι, id est, solam in hoc conjeciuram sequun- tur. _Rectius Schol. Rom. zoig ποιμέσι· καλῶς δὲ τοῦτο, iva μὴ παραγένοιτό τις ἀπαγγέλλων To σαφές. Sic ποιμ- νίων ἐπιστάταις Plat. Legg. X. 906. A. V. 28. Αἰτίαν νέμει. Codd. A. La. Lb. Aug. B. τρέπει, hic supra seripto νέμει. IIlud Valckenarius ad Hipp. p- 306. e,glossa eis αὐτὸν τρέπει ortum putat. Galenus de Plenit. c. XI. 346. T. VII. Chart. p. 582. Kuehn. οὐκ ἴσην ἅπασι νέμει τὴν alviav. V. 29. Keil μοί τις ὀπτήρ- εἰσιδών — haec verba ap- ponit Thomas s. Orryje, lolum versum cum insequenti Suidas s. Ὀπτῆρας, quam vocem Eustathius p. 788, 31. ex h. |. affert. Ep. Pr. V. 30. Πηδῶντα nedie. E Scholiastae interpreta- mento τῷ πεδίῳ nata est codd. nonnullorum lectio πεδίῳ. Syntaxis hujus exempla abunde multa extant, sed regula parum claret; πλανηθῆναι τὴν ἐρήμην lesai. XVI. 8. πολ- λὴν ἐρημίαν Conon. Narr. II. πολλὴν γῆν Xenoph. Eph. V. 14, 116. Plutarch. Lucull. e. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾷσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν ἀπίαν ἀλώμενος Oed. C. 1686: τὴν πλανοστιβῆ γῆν Beßus Aesch. Eum. 76.

ocr.line: de Plenit. c. Xl. 346. T. VII. Chart. p. 582. Kuehn. οὐκ
ocr.region: adjici ut lectores integrioris formae admoneantur. Mr θελήσας Isaeus Cir. p.69. $.11. zu} θέλοι Lycurg. Leoer. p. 157, 77. etc. et similia apud Demosthenem, cui Schaeferus μὴ ἐθέλειν eximere studet ad p. 1451, 61. cf. Ruediger ad Philipp. I. p. 27. Thuoydidi familiarius verbum trisyllabum , nee dubita- tione caruit ei θέλοιμεν VI. 34, A. sed Platoni jure reli- quit Schneiderus ad Civ. T. I. p. 230. T. III. p. 15%. etsi apud hunc ut apud ceteros antiquiores praevalet ἐθέλειν. V. 25. Ἐφθαρμένας — Hunc et insequentem versum producit Suidas s. Asius. Verbum κατηναρισμένας ex h. l. idem et Ilesychius et Schol. Ven. XXI. 26. enotarunt. Quod sequitur, ποιμνίων ἐπιστάταις, id Suidas s. Ἐπιστάτις in- terpretatur zeig «vol, fortasse ne Ajax caedis verae nec ad vindictam necessariae reus agatur; idemque sensisse videtur gui v. 232. adseripsit: οὗτοι γὰρ ἐνόμιζον καὶ ποιμένας αὐτὸν ἀνῃρηκέναι, id est, solam in hoc conjeciuram sequun- tur. _Rectius Schol. Rom. zoig ποιμέσι· καλῶς δὲ τοῦτο, iva μὴ παραγένοιτό τις ἀπαγγέλλων To σαφές. Sic ποιμ- νίων ἐπιστάταις Plat. Legg. X. 906. A. V. 28. Αἰτίαν νέμει. Codd. A. La. Lb. Aug. B. τρέπει, hic supra seripto νέμει. IIlud Valckenarius ad Hipp. p- 306. e,glossa eis αὐτὸν τρέπει ortum putat. Galenus de Plenit. c. XI. 346. T. VII. Chart. p. 582. Kuehn. οὐκ ἴσην ἅπασι νέμει τὴν alviav. V. 29. Keil μοί τις ὀπτήρ- εἰσιδών — haec verba ap- ponit Thomas s. Orryje, lolum versum cum insequenti Suidas s. Ὀπτῆρας, quam vocem Eustathius p. 788, 31. ex h. |. affert. Ep. Pr. V. 30. Πηδῶντα nedie. E Scholiastae interpreta- mento τῷ πεδίῳ nata est codd. nonnullorum lectio πεδίῳ. Syntaxis hujus exempla abunde multa extant, sed regula parum claret; πλανηθῆναι τὴν ἐρήμην lesai. XVI. 8. πολ- λὴν ἐρημίαν Conon. Narr. II. πολλὴν γῆν Xenoph. Eph. V. 14, 116. Plutarch. Lucull. e. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾷσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν ἀπίαν ἀλώμενος Oed. C. 1686: τὴν πλανοστιβῆ γῆν Beßus Aesch. Eum. 76.

Ὀπτῆρας, quam vocem Eustathius p. 788, 31. ex h. |. affert. Ep. Pr. V. 30. Πηδῶντα nedie. E Scholiastae interpreta- mento τῷ πεδίῳ nata est codd. nonnullorum lectio πεδίῳ. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾷσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν χθόνα πλανηθεῖν Eur. Hel. 728. κόμμηθε τῆς πλανηθῆς τὸν οἰκήτην Eur. Hel. 1057. δυσπόρηθεν ἐκ πανοίης πλάνηθεν Eur. Hel. 1061. πλανηθῆναι πολὺν ἔργων Eur. Hel. 1083. οὐκ ἐστὶ δὲ ἔστιν τὸν ἄνευ τῆς πλανηθῆς οὐδὲ πλεῖστον τοῦ παράπειρος Eur. Hel. 1092. οὐδὲν δὲ ἔστι τὸ πλῆθος τῆς πλανηθῆς Eur. Hel. 1094. ἠρύσει δὲ τὸ μὴ πρὸς τὴν πλανηθῆν ἀνθρώπου τὴν μὲν δύο, ἀνθρώπῳ ἀπὸ ἑτέρων, ἀνεκάλεων, ἀνεγράφων τῆς μὲν κόσμης, τοῦτό ἐστιν τὸ μὴ ἀπὸ μνήμης. πᾶσαν πλεῖστον τοῦ παράπειρος Eur. ocr.region: adjici ut lectores integrioris formae admoneantur. Mr θελήσας Isaeus Cir. p.69. $.11. zu} θέλοι Lycurg. Leoer. p. 157, 77. etc. et similia apud Demosthenem, cui Schaeferus μὴ ἐθέλειν eximere studet ad p. 1451, 61. cf. Ruediger ad Philipp. I. p. 27. Thuoydidi familiarius verbum trisyllabum , nee dubita- tione caruit ei θέλοιμεν VI. 34, A. sed Platoni jure reli- quit Schneiderus ad Civ. T. I. p. 230. T. III. p. 15%. etsi apud hunc ut apud ceteros antiquiores praevalet ἐθέλειν. V. 25. Ἐφθαρμένας — Hunc et insequentem versum producit Suidas s. Asius. Verbum κατηναρισμένας ex h. l. idem et Ilesychius et Schol. Ven. XXI. 26. enotarunt. Quod sequitur, ποιμνίων ἐπιστάταις, id Suidas s. Ἐπιστάτις in- terpretatur zeig «vol, fortasse ne Ajax caedis verae nec ad vindictam necessariae reus agatur; idemque sensisse videtur gui v. 232. adseripsit: οὗτοι γὰρ ἐνόμιζον καὶ ποιμένας αὐτὸν ἀνῃρηκέναι, id est, solam in hoc conjeciuram sequun- tur. _Rectius Schol. groundtruth.region: adjici ut lectores integrioris formae admoneantur. Μὴ θελήσας lsaeus Cir. p. 69. §. 11. μὴ θέλοι Lycurg. Leocr. p. 157, 77. etc. et similia apud Demosthenem, cui Schaeferus μὴ ἐθέλειν eximere studet ad p. 1451, 61. cf. Ruediger ad Philipp. I. p. 27. Thucydidi familiarius verbum trisyllabum, nec dubita- tione caruit εἰ θέλοιμεν Vl. 34, ⟨. sed Platoni jure reli- quit Schneiderus ad Civ. T. I. p. 230. T. III. p. 154. etsi apud hunc ut apud ceteros antiquiores praevalet ἐθέλειν. V. 25. Ἐφθαρμένας - Hunc et insequentem versum producit Suidas s. Λείας. Verbum κατηναρισμένας ex h. l. idem et Hesychius et Schol. Ven. XXI. 26. enotarunt. Quod sequitur, ποιμνίων ἐπιστάταις, id Suidas s. Ἐπιστάτις in- terpretatur τοῖς κυσί, fortasse ne Ajax caedis verae nec ad vindictam necessariae reus agatur ; idemque sensisse videtur qui v. 232. adscripsit : οὗτοι γὰρ ἐνόμιζον καὶ ποιμένας αὐτὸν ἀνῃρηκέναι, id est, solam in hoc conjecturam sequun- tur. Rectius Schol. Rom. τοῖς ποιμέσι· καλῶς δὲ τοῦτο, ἵνα μὴ παραγένοιτό τις ἀπαγγέλλων τὸ σαφές. Sic ποιμ- νίων ἐπιστάταις Plat. Legg. X. 906. A. V. 28. Αἰτίαν νέμει. Codd. Δ. La. Lb. Aug. B. τρέπει, hic supra scripto νέμει. Illud Valckenarius ad Hipp. p. 306. e glossa εἰς αὐτὸν τρέπει ortum putat. Galenus de Plenit. c. Xl. 346. T. VII. Chart. p. 582. Kuehn. οὐκ ἴσην ἅπασι νέμει τὴν αἰτίαν. V. 29. Καί μοί τις ὀπτήρ - εἰςιδών - haec verba ap- ponit Thomas s. Ὀπτήρ, totum versum cum insequenti Suidas s. Ὀπτῆρας, quam vocem Eustathius p. 788, 31. ex h. l. affert. ED. PR. V. 30 Πηδῶντα πεδία. E Scholiastae interpreta- mento τῷ πεδίῳ nata est codd. nonnullorum lectio πεδίῳ. Syntaxis hujus exempla abunde multa extant, sed regula parum claret ; πλανηθῆναι τὴν ἐρήμην Iesai. XVI. 8. πολ- λήν ἐρημίαν Conon. Narr. II. πολλὴν γῆν Xenoph. Eph. V. 14, 116. Plutarch. Lucull. c. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾶσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν ἀπίαν ἀλώμενος 0ed. C. 1686. τὴν πλανοστιβῆ γῆν βεβώς Aesch, Eum. 76.

Ἐπιστάτις in- terpretatur zeig «vol, fortasse ne Ajax caedis verae nec ad vindictam necessariae reus agatur; idemque sensisse videtur gui v. 232. adseripsit: οὗτοι γὰρ ἐνόμιζον καὶ ποιμένας αὐτὸν ἀνῃρηκέναι, id est, solam in hoc conjeciuram sequun- tur. _Rectius Schol. Rom. zoig ποιμέσι· καλῶς δὲ τοῦτο, iva μὴ παραγένοιτό τις ἀπαγγέλλων To σαφές. Sic ποιμ- νίων ἐπιστάταις Plat. Legg. X. 906. A. V. 28. Αἰτίαν νέμει. Codd. A. La. Lb. Aug. B. τρέπει, hic supra seripto νέμει. IIlud Valckenarius ad Hipp. p- 306. e,glossa eis αὐτὸν τρέπει ortum putat. Galenus de Plenit. c. XI. 346. T. VII. Chart. p. 582. Kuehn. οὐκ ἴσην ἅπασι νέμει τὴν alviav. V. 29. Keil μοί τις ὀπτήρ- εἰσιδών — haec verba ap- ponit Thomas s. Orryje, lolum versum cum insequenti Suidas s. Ὀπτῆρας, quam vocem Eustathius p. 788, 31. ex h. |. affert. Ep. Pr. V. 30. Πηδῶντα nedie. E Scholiastae interpreta- mento τῷ πεδίῳ nata est codd. nonnullorum lectio πεδίῳ. Syntaxis hujus exempla abunde multa extant, sed regula parum claret; πλανηθῆναι τὴν ἐρήμην lesai. XVI. 8. πολ- λὴν ἐρημίαν Conon. Narr. II. πολλὴν γῆν Xenoph. Eph. V. 14, 116. Plutarch. Lucull. e. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾷσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν ἀπίαν ἀλώμενος Oed. C. 1686: τὴν πλανοστιβῆ γῆν Beßus Aesch. Eum. 76.

Hel. 1097. ἦρξα δὲ τῆς πλανηθῆς ὡς ἀπὸ τῆς ἐξ ἀνθρώπων κόσμου ἕτερα γῆς Eur. Hel. 1100. πλὴν ἑνῆς γῆς Eur. Hel. 1101. πάθη μὲν οὖν τὴν πλανηθῆν γῆν ἑτέρων ἔργων, ἐπὶ τῆς δὲ μνήμης Eur. Hel. 1111. ὡς γὰρ πλανηθῆναι ἀνάρχεια, ὡς μύθη καὶ οὐκ οἶσθον τὴν ἡσυχῆν πνεῦμα οὐδὲ τὴν ἐν τῇ ἐξ αὐτῶν πνευμάτων ἀκούσασιν Eur. Hel. 1135. πλῆθος ἥρᾶτο ἥρᾶτο πλανηθῆναι Eur. Hel. 1146. πλανηθῆναι γὰρ ἐστὶ ἡ ἀρχὴ ἡ ἁπάντη Eur. Hel. 1152. πλανηθῆναι γὰρ ἡ συνέβη Eur. Hel. 1156. οὐκ εἶχεν ὁ δὲ μῆθος πλανηθῆναι Eur. Hel. 1163. ἕτερον γὰρ πλὴν ἑτέρον πλάνηθεν Eur. Hel. 1183. πᾶσαν πολύπλανος Eur. Hel. 1187. πολύπλατος Eur. Hel. 1188. πλῆθος πολύπλατος Eur. Hel. 1189. πολύπλατος Eur. Hel. 1191. πολύπλατος Eur. Hel. 1192. πολύπλατος Eur. ocr.line: λήν ἐρημίαν Conon. Narr. II. πολλὴν γῆν Xenoph. Eph.
ocr.region: adjici ut lectores integrioris formae admoneantur. Mr θελήσας Isaeus Cir. p.69. $.11. zu} θέλοι Lycurg. Leoer. p. 157, 77. etc. et similia apud Demosthenem, cui Schaeferus μὴ ἐθέλειν eximere studet ad p. 1451, 61. cf. Ruediger ad Philipp. I. p. 27. Thuoydidi familiarius verbum trisyllabum , nee dubita- tione caruit ei θέλοιμεν VI. 34, A. sed Platoni jure reli- quit Schneiderus ad Civ. T. I. p. 230. T. III. p. 15%. etsi apud hunc ut apud ceteros antiquiores praevalet ἐθέλειν. V. 25. Ἐφθαρμένας — Hunc et insequentem versum producit Suidas s. Asius. Verbum κατηναρισμένας ex h. l. idem et Ilesychius et Schol. Ven. XXI. 26. enotarunt. Quod sequitur, ποιμνίων ἐπιστάταις, id Suidas s. Ἐπιστάτις in- terpretatur zeig «vol, fortasse ne Ajax caedis verae nec ad vindictam necessariae reus agatur; idemque sensisse videtur gui v. 232. adseripsit: οὗτοι γὰρ ἐνόμιζον καὶ ποιμένας αὐτὸν ἀνῃρηκέναι, id est, solam in hoc conjeciuram sequun- tur. _Rectius Schol. Rom. zoig ποιμέσι· καλῶς δὲ τοῦτο, iva μὴ παραγένοιτό τις ἀπαγγέλλων To σαφές. Sic ποιμ- νίων ἐπιστάταις Plat. Legg. X. 906. A. V. 28. Αἰτίαν νέμει. Codd. A. La. Lb. Aug. B. τρέπει, hic supra seripto νέμει. IIlud Valckenarius ad Hipp. p- 306. e,glossa eis αὐτὸν τρέπει ortum putat. Galenus de Plenit. c. XI. 346. T. VII. Chart. p. 582. Kuehn. οὐκ ἴσην ἅπασι νέμει τὴν alviav. V. 29. Keil μοί τις ὀπτήρ- εἰσιδών — haec verba ap- ponit Thomas s. Orryje, lolum versum cum insequenti Suidas s. Ὀπτῆρας, quam vocem Eustathius p. 788, 31. ex h. |. affert. Ep. Pr. V. 30. Πηδῶντα nedie. E Scholiastae interpreta- mento τῷ πεδίῳ nata est codd. nonnullorum lectio πεδίῳ. Syntaxis hujus exempla abunde multa extant, sed regula parum claret; πλανηθῆναι τὴν ἐρήμην lesai. XVI. 8. πολ- λὴν ἐρημίαν Conon. Narr. II. πολλὴν γῆν Xenoph. Eph. V. 14, 116. Plutarch. Lucull. e. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾷσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν ἀπίαν ἀλώμενος Oed. C. 1686: τὴν πλανοστιβῆ γῆν Beßus Aesch. Eum. 76.

Thuoydidi familiarius verbum trisyllabum , nee dubita- tione caruit ei θέλοιμεν VI. 34, A. sed Platoni jure reli- quit Schneiderus ad Civ. T. I. p. 230. T. III. p. 15%. etsi apud hunc ut apud ceteros antiquiores praevalet ἐθέλειν. V. 25. Ἐφθαρμένας — Hunc et insequentem versum producit Suidas s. Asius. Verbum κατηναρισμένας ex h. l. idem et Ilesychius et Schol. Ven. XXI. 26. enotarunt. Quod sequitur, ποιμνίων ἐπιστάταις, id Suidas s. Ἐπιστάτις in- terpretatur zeig «vol, fortasse ne Ajax caedis verae nec ad vindictam necessariae reus agatur; idemque sensisse videtur gui v. 232. adseripsit: οὗτοι γὰρ ἐνόμιζον καὶ ποιμένας αὐτὸν ἀνῃρηκέναι, id est, solam in hoc conjeciuram sequun- tur. _Rectius Schol. Rom. zoig ποιμέσι· καλῶς δὲ τοῦτο, iva μὴ παραγένοιτό τις ἀπαγγέλλων To σαφές. Sic ποιμ- νίων ἐπιστάταις Plat. Legg. X. 906. A. V. 28. Αἰτίαν νέμει. Codd. A. La. Lb. Aug. B. τρέπει, hic supra seripto νέμει. IIlud Valckenarius ad Hipp. p- 306. e,glossa eis αὐτὸν τρέπει ortum putat. Galenus de Plenit. c. XI. 346. T. VII. Chart. p. 582. Kuehn. οὐκ ἴσην ἅπασι νέμει τὴν alviav. V. 29. Keil μοί τις ὀπτήρ- εἰσιδών — haec verba ap- ponit Thomas s. Orryje, lolum versum cum insequenti Suidas s. Ὀπτῆρας, quam vocem Eustathius p. 788, 31. ex h. |. affert. Ep. Pr. V. 30. Πηδῶντα nedie. E Scholiastae interpreta- mento τῷ πεδίῳ nata est codd. nonnullorum lectio πεδίῳ. Syntaxis hujus exempla abunde multa extant, sed regula parum claret; πλανηθῆναι τὴν ἐρήμην lesai. XVI. 8. πολ- λὴν ἐρημίαν Conon. Narr. II. πολλὴν γῆν Xenoph. Eph. V. 14, 116. Plutarch. Lucull. e. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾷσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν χθόνα πλανηθεῖν Eur. Hel. 728. κόμμηθε τῆς πλανηθῆς τὸν οἰκήτην Eur. Hel. 1057. δυσπόρηθεν ἐκ πανοίης πλάνηθεν Eur. Hel. 1061. πλανηθῆναι πολὺν ἔργων Eur. Hel. 1083. οὐκ ἐστὶ δὲ ἔστιν τὸν ἄνευ τῆς πλανηθῆς οὐδὲ πλεῖστον τοῦ παράπειρος Eur. Hel. 1092. οὐδὲν δὲ ἔστι τὸ πλῆθος τῆς πλανηθῆς Eur. Hel. 1094. ἠρύσει δὲ τὸ μὴ πρὸς τὴν πλανηθῆν ἀνθρώπου τὴν μὲν δύο, ἀνθρώπῳ ἀπὸ ἑτέρων, ἀνεκάλεων, ἀνεγράφων τῆς μὲν κόσμης, τοῦτό ἐστιν τὸ μὴ ἀπὸ μνήμης. πᾶσαν πλεῖστον τοῦ παράπειρος Eur. Hel. 1094. τὸ δὲ πλῆθος μὴ πρὸς τοῦ παράπειρος ἕτερον γὰρ πλῆθος ποι- mέως ἐπίστευσε, id est, πλὴν ἀνάρχεως ὁρᾶται, πλῆθος ἀπὸ ἑτέρων, ἀνεκάλεων, ἀνεγράφων τῆς ἐν τῷ κόσμῳ πλῆθος. ἀπὸ τοῦ μνήμου Eur. Hel. 1097. ἦρξα δὲ τῆς πλανηθῆς ὡς ἀπὸ τῆς ἐξ ἀνθρώπων κόσμου ἕτερα γῆς Eur. Hel. 1100. πλὴν ἑνῆς γῆς Eur. Hel. 1101. πάθη μὲν οὖν τὴν πλανηθῆν γῆν ἑτέρων ἔργων, ἐπὶ τῆς δὲ μνήμης Eur. Hel. 1111. ὡς γὰρ πλανηθῆναι ἀνάρχεια, ὡς μύθη καὶ οὐκ οἶσθον τὴν ἡσυχῆν πνεῦμα οὐδὲ τὴν ἐν τῇ ἐξ αὐτῶν πνευμάτων ἀκούσασιν Eur. Hel. 1135. πλῆθος ἥρᾶτο ἥρᾶτο πλανηθῆναι Eur. Hel. 1146. πλανηθῆναι γὰρ ἐστὶ ἡ ἀρχὴ ἡ ἁπάντη Eur. Hel. 1152. πλανηθῆναι γὰρ ἡ συνέβη Eur. Hel. 1156. οὐκ εἶχεν ὁ δὲ μῆθος πλανηθῆναι Eur. Hel. 1163. ἕτερον γὰρ πλὴν ἑτέρον πλάνηθεν Eur. Hel. 1183. πᾶσαν πολύπλανος Eur. Hel. 1187. πολύπλατος Eur. Hel. 1188. πλῆθος πολύπλατος Eur. Hel. 1189. πολύπλατος Eur. Hel. 1191. πολύπλατος Eur. Hel. 1192. πολύπλατος Eur. Hel. 1195. τὸ δὲ πλῆθος πολύπλανος Eur. Hel. 1196. πλῆθος πολύπλανος Eur. Hel. 1197. πλῆθος πολύπλανος Eur. Hel. 1198. πολύ

Ὀπτῆρας, quam vocem Eustathius p. 788, 31. ex h. l. affert. ED. PR. V. 30 Πηδῶντα πεδία. E Scholiastae interpreta- mento τῷ πεδίῳ nata est codd. nonnullorum lectio πεδίῳ. Do not write anything else than the corrected text.

Rom. zoig ποιμέσι· καλῶς δὲ τοῦτο, iva μὴ παραγένοιτό τις ἀπαγγέλλων To σαφές. Sic ποιμ- νίων ἐπιστάταις Plat. Legg. X. 906. A. V. 28. Αἰτίαν νέμει. Codd. A. La. Lb. Aug. B. τρέπει, hic supra seripto νέμει. IIlud Valckenarius ad Hipp. p- 306. e,glossa eis αὐτὸν τρέπει ortum putat. Galenus de Plenit. c. XI. 346. T. VII. Chart. p. 582. Kuehn. οὐκ ἴσην ἅπασι νέμει τὴν alviav. V. 29. Keil μοί τις ὀπτήρ- εἰσιδών — haec verba ap- ponit Thomas s. Orryje, lolum versum cum insequenti Suidas s. Ὀπτῆρας, quam vocem Eustathius p. 788, 31. ex h. |. affert. Ep. Pr. V. 30. Πηδῶντα nedie. E Scholiastae interpreta- mento τῷ πεδίῳ nata est codd. nonnullorum lectio πεδίῳ. Syntaxis hujus exempla abunde multa extant, sed regula parum claret; πλανηθῆναι τὴν ἐρήμην lesai. XVI. 8. πολ- λὴν ἐρημίαν Conon. Narr. II. πολλὴν γῆν Xenoph. Eph. V. 14, 116. Plutarch. Lucull. e. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾷσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν ἀπίαν ἀλώμενος Oed. C. 1686: τὴν πλανοστιβῆ γῆν Beßus Aesch. Eum. 76.

Hel. 1097. ἦρξα δὲ τῆς πλανηθῆς ὡς ἀπὸ τῆς ἐξ ἀνθρώπων κόσμου ἕτερα γῆς Eur. Hel. 1100. πλὴν ἑνῆς γῆς Eur. Hel. 1101. πάθη μὲν οὖν τὴν πλανηθῆν γῆν ἑτέρων ἔργων, ἐπὶ τῆς δὲ μνήμης Eur. Hel. 1111. ὡς γὰρ πλανηθῆναι ἀνάρχεια, ὡς μύθη καὶ οὐκ οἶσθον τὴν ἡσυχῆν πνεῦμα οὐδὲ τὴν ἐν τῇ ἐξ αὐτῶν πνευμάτων ἀκούσασιν Eur. Hel. 1135. πλῆθος ἥρᾶτο ἥρᾶτο πλανηθῆναι Eur. Hel. 1146. πλανηθῆναι γὰρ ἐστὶ ἡ ἀρχὴ ἡ ἁπάντη Eur. Hel. 1152. πλανηθῆναι γὰρ ἡ συνέβη Eur. Hel. 1156. οὐκ εἶχεν ὁ δὲ μῆθος πλανηθῆναι Eur. Hel. 1163. ἕτερον γὰρ πλὴν ἑτέρον πλάνηθεν Eur. Hel. 1183. πᾶσαν πολύπλανος Eur. Hel. 1187. πολύπλατος Eur. Hel. 1188. πλῆθος πολύπλατος Eur. Hel. 1189. πολύπλατος Eur. Hel. 1191. πολύπλατος Eur. Hel. 1192. πολύπλατος Eur. Hel. 1195. τὸ δὲ πλῆθος πολύπλανος Eur. Hel. 1196. πλῆθος πολύπλανος Eur. Hel. 1197. πλῆθος πολύπλανος Eur. Hel. 1198. πολύ

ocr.line: de Plenit. c. Xl. 346. T. VII. Chart. p. 582. Kuehn. οὐκ
ocr.region: adjici ut lectores integrioris formae admoneantur. Mr θελήσας Isaeus Cir. p.69. $.11. zu} θέλοι Lycurg. Leoer. p. 157, 77. etc. et similia apud Demosthenem, cui Schaeferus μὴ ἐθέλειν eximere studet ad p. 1451, 61. cf. Ruediger ad Philipp. I. p. 27. Thuoydidi familiarius verbum trisyllabum , nee dubita- tione caruit ei θέλοιμεν VI. 34, A. sed Platoni jure reli- quit Schneiderus ad Civ. T. I. p. 230. T. III. p. 15%. etsi apud hunc ut apud ceteros antiquiores praevalet ἐθέλειν. V. 25. Ἐφθαρμένας — Hunc et insequentem versum producit Suidas s. Asius. Verbum κατηναρισμένας ex h. l. idem et Ilesychius et Schol. Ven. XXI. 26. enotarunt. Quod sequitur, ποιμνίων ἐπιστάταις, id Suidas s. Ἐπιστάτις in- terpretatur zeig «vol, fortasse ne Ajax caedis verae nec ad vindictam necessariae reus agatur; idemque sensisse videtur gui v. 232. adseripsit: οὗτοι γὰρ ἐνόμιζον καὶ ποιμένας αὐτὸν ἀνῃρηκέναι, id est, solam in hoc conjeciuram sequun- tur. _Rectius Schol. Rom. zoig ποιμέσι· καλῶς δὲ τοῦτο, iva μὴ παραγένοιτό τις ἀπαγγέλλων To σαφές. Sic ποιμ- νίων ἐπιστάταις Plat. Legg. X. 906. A. V. 28. Αἰτίαν νέμει. Codd. A. La. Lb. Aug. B. τρέπει, hic supra seripto νέμει. IIlud Valckenarius ad Hipp. p- 306. e,glossa eis αὐτὸν τρέπει ortum putat. Galenus de Plenit. c. XI. 346. T. VII. Chart. p. 582. Kuehn. οὐκ ἴσην ἅπασι νέμει τὴν alviav. V. 29. Keil μοί τις ὀπτήρ- εἰσιδών — haec verba ap- ponit Thomas s. Orryje, lolum versum cum insequenti Suidas s. Ὀπτῆρας, quam vocem Eustathius p. 788, 31. ex h. |. affert. Ep. Pr. V. 30. Πηδῶντα nedie. E Scholiastae interpreta- mento τῷ πεδίῳ nata est codd. nonnullorum lectio πεδίῳ. Syntaxis hujus exempla abunde multa extant, sed regula parum claret; πλανηθῆναι τὴν ἐρήμην lesai. XVI. 8. πολ- λὴν ἐρημίαν Conon. Narr. II. πολλὴν γῆν Xenoph. Eph. V. 14, 116. Plutarch. Lucull. e. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾷσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν ἀπίαν ἀλώμενος Oed. C. 1686: τὴν πλανοστιβῆ γῆν Beßus Aesch. Eum. 76.

It is better not to think that the world is created; rather,
one should not think that it was not created.
If a human is born, he is born to the world, and the
world is not created for him; if a human is born to the
world, the world is born to him.

It is better to know this than to be mistaken in the matter
of life.

It is better to know this than to be deceived by the
evildoers.

He who sees the world as created is one who has not been
blinded

ocr.line: the fiery man.’ Essay on L. § 9. p. 12, 2.
ocr.region: the fiery man. Essay on L. §9. P. 12, 2. If τοι is retained in infr. 245, we may read here οἵαν ἐδήλωσας *kar avdpis αἴθονος. The short syllable in αἴθονος is sufficiently supported by at6ova occur- ring in Hesychius in the right alpha- betical order (immediately after alo1). Although αἴθοπος (see v. r1.) may be defended, on the ground that the second part of a compound has sometimes little significance (see esp. infr. 954, κελαι- νῶπαν θυμόν), yet αἴθων, which directly expresses character, is more appropriate here, and has the preponderance of MS. authority in its favour. 222. ἄτλατον οὐδὲ φευκτάν] ‘That can neither be avoided nor endared.’ 225. μεγάλων] ‘Terrible.’ The mari- ners, in their feebleness (supr. 165 foll.), are afraid of the opinion of the host. These words are added as a commenut on οὐδὲ φευκτάν. The consequences of the fact cannot be eluded, since it is known to the host, and magnified by rumour. 226. ὁ pyasus) ‘The formidable power of rumour.’ Supr. 172, & μεγάλα φάτις. μῦθος is the rumour about this particular thing, with a suggestion of rumour in geneial. ἀέξει] Not "exaggerates,’ for the evil could not be exaggerated, but, ‘which the mighty power of rumour spreads abroad.’

The short syllable in αἴθονος is sufficiently supported by αἴθονα occur- ring in Hesychius in the right alpha- betical order (immediately after αἶθον). Although αἴθοπος (see v. rr.) may be defended, on the ground that the second part of a compound has sometimes little significance (see esp. infr. 954, κελαι- νώπαν θυμόν), yet αἴθων, which directly expresses character, is more appropriate here, and has the preponderance of MS. authority in its favour. 222. ἄτλατον οὐδὲ φευκτάν] ‘That can neither be avoided nor endured.’ 225. μεγάλων] ‘Terrible.’ The mari- ners, in their feebleness (supr. 165 foll.), are afraid of the opinion of the host. These words are added as a comment on οὐδὲ φευκτάν. The consequences of the fact cannot be eluded, since it is known to the host, and magnified by rumour. 226. ὁ μέγας μῦθος] ‘The formidable power of rumour.’ Supr. 172, ὦ μεγάλα φάτις. μῦθος is the rumour about this particular thing, with a suggestion of rumour in general. ἀέξει] Not ‘exaggerates,’ for the evil could not be exaggerated, but, ‘which the mighty power of rumour spreads abroad.’

In our current workflow, we usually run an OCR program on a text (e.g. Tesseract or Txt2Html) and check for spelling mistakes and other grammatical errors. If there are errors that can be corrected by the software, then they are corrected. If the software cannot correct the mistakes, then we take a look at the text and try to make sense of the meaning.

prediction.line:
‘he smote beneath the ribs, and ripped’

I’ve done some research and found that this is a common error. For instance, in the commentary on Virgil’s Aeneid by Thomas Moore, there are four occurrences of the error, but only in the first book of the epic (the first of the six books that compose it). In the commentary by Pierre de La Rue there are also several cases of the error, but only in book three. In my own corpus of commentaries on Virgil’s Aeneid, I’ve found three cases in book four.

prediction.sentence:
231.
This chapter is the one which relates to the different forms which
  were originally used for the expression of time, and which were
  afterwards changed. The chapter has two parts. The first treats of
  the different forms which were originally used. The second part
  treats of the causes which led to the change of the forms, and the
  manner in which they came to be adopted.
231.1.1.1. The three different forms of time were: a. The present, by
  which all things were indicated; b. The future, as that which was
  meant in the future, or which was to follow; c. The past, as that
  which had been previously spoken of, or

407 foll.



In the first volume of his Commentaries on the Greek and Latin Fathers
Pseudo-Macarius mentions this verse of Augustine.

According to the notes by M. Bury, this would be chapter 5, p. 407; but
the note by M. G. Baker is much more clear, and reads (on page 4, second
line above the note by M. Bury):

"Excerpta sive Notes ad Commentum patres Graecis et Latinis: 5. 407 foll."

In the footnote to this volume, p. 411, this edition is described as the
"translation of the text of the Latin version of the Comment

prediction.region:
488. If a king’s actions prove harmful, then it is his duty, to avoid them if possible.
490. Most men fear being led astray, for they fear the dangers they may meet
in the pursuit of the wealth of this world; but Ajax is the bravest of men and
takes the road of honour.

491. It is not that his courage has increased, but that he is the most skilled
of warriors and has learnt to make the best of everything.

A:

You need to change σθένει πλούτου to σθένει μετίγραφόν. The reason is the omission of πλούτου. It is a common mistake that people often commit in their OCR. In any case the correct spelling is as follows and you need to put it in parentheses when it appears in the text:

2, σθένει μετίγραφόν; Eur.

Another example with the same correction can be found in a transcription of a contemporary document:

2, σθένει μετίγραφόν; Eur.</s>

CONTEXT:
This chapter discusses the issue of how far the commandments of the Torah are subject to
innovation and interpretation. The tradition that was transmitted from Moses through
the prophets states that the Torah is not subject to innovation, but it does not
exclude the possibility of interpretation. The commentary of Rashi on this chapter
asserts that it is indeed a matter of interpretation, but he points out that it is
not possible to distinguish which interpretations are correct. His discussion
includes a very specific description of the different kinds of innovations, and he
shows how they can be differentiated in the Talmudic discussions.</s>

715.


The work of the ancients and of the moderns is equally important to us. It is the study of their lives, the
thoughts and beliefs, and the words and works that make us what we are, that leads us to find out why things
are the way they are, what to expect and to accept. We can learn much from their lives and what they experienced; and the
study of their thoughts and beliefs is equally important for us. We cannot know everything they thought and believed, and
we can gain nothing if we pretend we have; but we can learn from their thoughts and beliefs how the ancient world understood
life and the world, and how they perceived the human experience. In

For the poetical plural, ‘outbursts of wrath.’ cp. Trach. 882, rtves νόσοι; and see Essay on L. § 20. p. 30. The plural of θυμός occurs in Plat. Phil. 40 E: Legg. 11. 034 A, 6 δὲ .. ἐν φόβοις δειλίας, 5 τῖσιν ἐπιθυμίαις ἢ φθόνοις Gupols δυ- σιάτοις γιγνόμενος. (νεικεῶν.) 719 foll. The proscenium has been vacant during the preceding ode. A single figure is now seen approaching from the opposite direction to that in which Ajax went forth. The man proves to be Teucer’s forerunner. ñ The effect of the following scene is twofold. On the one hand, the Chorus and Tecmessa are roused from their security, and go anxiously in search of Teucer, whose appearance on the scene has excited them so much surprise. On the other hand, Teucer’s appearance induces him to turn towards the audience, as he is evidently in danger of attack. This, however, is prevented by a sudden interruption. 720. οἱ μὲν γὰρ ἀπ’ αὐτὸν ἐφορώθησαν] ‘They heard from him that he was in need.’ The expression is in the same sense as ἤθυμον δέ, the reading of S; but here we have a special object which causes the word to be so applied. The text here quoted is a fragment of the Commentaries to Plato, written by Dionysius
the Areopagite during the late seventh century B.C. The text of this work was
discovered, among other writings, in the library of the University of Paris. The
book which contains this text was the library of Theophilus, Bishop of
Athens, who was a pupil of Plato, and therefore was himself a pupil of Dionysius.

30. Now it is necessary to determine what manner of sacrifice was that in
which the two animals were burnt and consumed. For if we suppose that
they were not consumed, but merely burnt, or that, although they were
consumed, the animals were not killed with a knife and thrust through
with an iron, it will not follow that the victim was a person, but only
that he was a beast or a goat. Now that was not the case with the
sacrifice of Abraham. When he burnt his sacrifice and consumed the
flesh, the burnt offering, the meat, he said: "Lift up your eyes now
and look toward the field, for to your field go I." [

The work of the ancients and of the moderns is equally important to us. It is the study of their lives, the
thoughts and beliefs, and the words and works that make us what we are, that leads us to find out why things
are the way they are, what to expect and to accept. We can learn much from their lives and what they experienced; and the
study of their thoughts and beliefs is equally important for us. We cannot know everything they thought and believed, and
we can gain nothing if we pretend we have; but we can learn from their thoughts and beliefs how the ancient world understood
life and the world, and how they perceived the human experience. In

prediction.sentence:
30. Now it is necessary to determine what manner of sacrifice was that in
which the two animals were burnt and consumed. For if we suppose that
they were not consumed, but merely burnt, or that, although they were
consumed, the animals were not killed with a knife and thrust through
with an iron, it will not follow that the victim was a person, but only
that he was a beast or a goat. Now that was not the case with the
sacrifice of Abraham. When he burnt his sacrifice and consumed the
flesh, the burnt offering, the meat, he said: "Lift up your eyes now
and look toward the field, for to your field go I." [

1. For to them that know God is the light increasing: but to them that
dwell in darkness (ignorance), the darkness hath increased. 2. Why
therefore, seeing we walk in the light as in the day, let us be not
careless, but giving all diligence, add to our faith virtue. 3. Let us not
lose out of our hearts the hope set before us, which seeing we have with
Christ Jesus: 4. Who hath saved us, and called us with a holy calling,
not according to our works, but according to his own purpose and grace
which was given us in Christ Jesus before the world began. 5. But if ye be

ocr.region: Ajax. We are thus made aware that the crisis of the drama is approaching. But, on the other hand, the bearing of the prophet to Teucer, as reported by the messenger, and the tenor of his prophecy, assure the spectator that the anger of Athena against Ajax is not lasting, and hold forth a vague promise of final peace. GvBpes φίλοι] The messenger, who is one of Teucer’s men, thus assures the mariners of his continued friendship in their master’s hour of need. τὸ πρῶτον stands in apposition with the sentence, Τεῦκρος παρέστι, which, as Hermann says, must be held as equivalent to Ted- xnov παρεῖναι. Cp. O. T. 1234, 5, 6 μὲν τάχιστοός τῶν λόγῶν εἰπεῖν τε Καὶ |μαθεῖν, τέθνηκε θεῖον Ἰοκάστης κάρα. The ab- ruptness of this gives some colour to Mausgrave’s conjecture, ἄνδρες, φίλον τὸ πρῶτον ἀγγεῖλαι θέλω. 724, 5. ‘For when they knew him from afar off as he approached, they surrounded him.’ Cp. infr. 1046, μαθεῖν γὰρ ἐγγὺς w οὐ δυσπετής. 726. κἀπιβουλευτοῦ στρατοῦ] ‘And

πρῶτον ἀγγεῖλαι θέλω.

prediction.line:
πρῶτον ἀγγέλῳ θέλω.


QUESTION:
Where did I make a mistake? Does it have to do with the grammar? Is there a simpler way to write the correct version?

A:

For clarity, the correct line is πρῶτον ἀγγέλῳ θέλω. The most important difference is that ἔν and ἔστι are not interchangeable. ἔν implies that there are no such things as multiple things, whereas ἔστι implies that a multiple can be distinguished from each other.</s>

A:

OCR is an automated process for converting a scanned text to text, using software to analyse, recognize and decode hand-written text in a document.  It is common in legal contexts where the hand-written text is legalistic and not as useful as it would be in a written document.
In order to have correct data available, you will need to either:
- get a second hand copy of the document and manually check any errors (if you don't already have one)
- get the document translated to modern text
- work with a copywriting specialist to get the correct information in place, and do all your checks on the translated version.

A:

OCR is an automated process for converting a scanned text to text, using software to analyse, recognize and decode hand-written text in a document.  It is common in legal contexts where the hand-written text is legalistic and not as useful as it would be in a written document.
In order to have correct data available, you will need to either:
- get a second hand copy of the document and manually check any errors (if you don't already have one)
- get the document translated to modern text
- work with a copywriting specialist to get the correct information in place, and do all your checks on the translated version.

1. This is a commentary on the Psalm 27 (cf. Ps 27:1).

comparison between the psalmist and his adversary, and the second a
declaration that the psalmist is to be judged on his conduct towards his
enemies. In these two clauses the psalmist makes a distinction between
his own righteousness and that of others. It was the way in which he
cared for those who were wicked and rebellious that would be the
object of his adversary's censure, whereas it would be his personal
virtue and his capacity for righteous

passionately assumes that her fate and happiness are bound up with
her husband's. There is nothing more dangerous than an unmarried

courtesy, and sometimes even with respect and courtesy. But
during her youth she is more frequently than not the cause of
much suffering and misery, if not the real cause of that suffering

786. ‘Cito al cuore.

A:

First sentence: the verb "to cut" is a transitive verb: it is in passive voice.
Second sentence:

‘Cito al cuore’

is a compound noun:

cito - it cut
al - to
cuore - heart
'It cuts the heart'.

The compound noun is an adjective modifying the noun "cut".

You need to replace all instances of the compound noun in your answer by the verb it modifies.</s>

The problem is that there are many different types of mistakes that can be made by OCR and different software can do different things well with those mistakes. A human can fix all these different mistakes easily, and the mistakes you have are all of them. In that case, there's a good chance that a human would find your corrections and accept them.
However, if the OCR software does not recognize some of these mistakes well, then the only option left is to fix those mistakes yourself. The following example is just one such case where the error can not be fixed easily by a human and the only option left is to do it by hand.

TEXTE D'ÉRASME CONSACRÉ À L'ACCEPTATION DE LA RÉVOLUTION. 1592
1594

L'âme de l'homme, et par conséquent la vie de l'homme, est la mesure
de toutes choses. Le ciel et la terre sont la même chose pour lui,
aussi bien que l'homme lui-même; il n'en est pas même ainsi pour un
animal; c'est là la loi universelle et nécessaire.

L'homme est, non un dieu, mais une âme, qui est semblable à un dieu.
L'âme est éternelle, et l'homme est, par son essence, une partie
de l'âme, quoiqu'elle soit inférieure à lui. Il y a un seul Dieu
unique

1 The second part of the book which is to follow in the next volume, begins
with an account of the first year of his reign.

2 But since the death of Cyprian and of Valerian, and the reign of
Antoninus Pius, and since there was a general resurrection of the arts,
a great number of writings have appeared both from philosophers and
authors, which are, to say the least, very little to be admired.

3 For in that time there were many men who wanted to be philosophers, and
very many who wanted to be good writers, but who had neither leisure nor
genius; and the more they wrote, the more they wanted to write

The antecedent κακοῖς is drawn into the relative clause, though here its case is not thereby affected: cp. Ant. 404 θάπτουσαν TO τὸν νεκρὸν ἀπεῖπας. (darera is far better than the v. . ovras: it hints what is meant by the vague κακοῖς. 274 κανέπνευσε after the actual cessation (ἔληξε), a brief space is still needed to permit ἀναπνοή. Cp. II. I1I. 382 ἀνέπνευσαν κακότητος: and n. on D. C. 1113 f. 2786 Instead of ketvos, we might have looked for atr6s: but the former has been preferred, because it better marks the antithesis between Ajax and his friends.—mds, adverbial: Ph. 386 πόλις γάρ ἐστι πᾶσα τῶν ἡγουμένων.- ἐλήλαται 7r. 1045 (συμφορὰς) olas.. ἐλαύνεται (n.). For the emphatic perf., cp. El. 64. Here it expresses that com- Blete prostration has at once followed the return of sanity: cp. Plat. Phaedo p. 80 D ἡ δὲ ψυχὴ . . ἀπαλλαττομένη τοῦ σώματος εὐθὺς διαπεφύσηται καὶ ἀπόλωλεν. 277 dp’=dp οὐ; O. T. 822 ãp' ἔφυν κακός; El. 6143.—B\s τόσ’ －διπλᾶ. Cp.

groundtruth.region: 272 f. οἷσιν εἴχετ’ ἐν κακοῖς = κακοῖς ἐν οἶς εἴχετο : cp. 1144 : Her. 9. 37 ἐν τούτῳ τῷ κακῷ ἐχόμενος. The antecedent κακοῖς is drawn into the relative clause, though here its case is not thereby affected: cp. Ant. 404 θάπτουσαν ὃν σὺ τὸν νεκρὸν | ἀπεῖπας. φρονοῦντας is far better than the v. l. βλέποντας: it hints what is meant by the vague κακοῖς. 274 κἀνέπνευσε : after the actual cessation (ἔληξε), a brief space is still needed to permit ἀναπνοή. Cp. Il. 11. 382 ἀνέπνευσαν κακότητος : and n. on O. C. 1113 f. 275 Instead of κεῖνος, we might have looked for αὐτός : but the former has been preferred, because it better marks the antithesis between Ajax and his friends.—πᾶς, adverbial : Ph. 386 πόλις γάρ ἐστι πᾶσα τῶν ἡγουμένων.— ἐλήλαται: Tr. 1045 (συμφορὰς) οἵαις.. ἐλαύνεται (n.). For the emphatic perf., cp. El. 64. Here it expresses that com- plete prostration has at once followed the return of sanity: cp. Plat. Phaedo p. 80 D ἡ δὲ ψυχὴ.. ἀπαλλαττομένη τοῦ σώματος εὐθὺς διαπεφύσηται καὶ ἀπόλωλεν.

prediction.line:
Xenophon:

The ancient Greek epic The Ajax and the Xenophon was probably written in the 4th century BC. The poem was dedicated to the poet Demosthenes and contains the famous duel between Ajax and Xenophon, the father of Alexander the Great.

Xenophon (ca. 460 BC) was a sophist and military commander of the Persians in Alexander's campaign against the Maccabees. He was a close friend of the Maccabees and participated in the battle at Dura. He was later a soldier in the Persian wars and served under Antigonus. (darera is far better than the v. . ovras: it hints what is meant by the vague κακοῖς. 274 κανέπνευσε after the actual cessation (ἔληξε), a brief space is still needed to permit ἀναπνοή. Cp. II. I1I. 382 ἀνέπνευσαν κακότητος: and n. on D. ocr.region: Ajax, whose mother was Eriboea (569). -rw doad.. xpbvov: the phrase τὸν del χρόνον is frequent. The separation of τὸν elcael from χρόνον deserves notice, as suggesting the possibility that τὸν del may sometimes have been used (without xp6- νον) as= "for ever’: a usage which, how- ever, lacks proof: see on El. 1075. — ANaroe : he had gone to the uplands of Mysia (720). "in pursuit of foes (564) to be despoiled. Cp. Thuc. 1. 11 81 (the Greeks at Troy) palvovrai... 7pb yewpylav τῆς Χερσονήσου τραπόμενοι καὶ λῃστείαν τῆς τροφῆς ἀπορίᾳ. The Iliad lances at such predatory expeditions 1. 366; 9. 328).—Note the light touch with which the poet accounts for the absence of Teucer—a necessity of the plets since Teucer might have averted his rother’s suicide. 844 £. dvolyere: a usual form of summons, addressed to no particular per- son, but to the inmates of the house enerally; Aesch. Ch. 877 ἀλλ’ dvolare: 5 Adelph. 4. 4. 26 aperite, aliquis. Ajax πρόσπολοι, though they were not at this time in the house (539).—We should not explain the plur. as addressed by the choregus to the choreutae and Tecmessa. al8a. MdBo: cp. Ph. 1078 φρόνησιν .. λάβοι; Tr. 669 f. προθυμίαν | .. \aBetv.—
groundtruth.region: Ajax, whose mother was Eriboea (569). —τὸν εἰσαεὶ .. χρόνον : the phrase τὸν ἀεὶ χρόνον is frequent. The separation of τὸν εἰσαεὶ from χρόνον deserves notice, as suggesting the possibility hat τὸν ἀεἰ may sometimes have been used (without χρό- νον) as = 'for ever ʼ: a usage which, how- ever, lacks proof: see on El. 1075.— λεηλατήσει: he had gone to the uplands of Mysia (720), 'in pursuit of foesʼ (564) to be despoiled. Cp. Thuc. I. II § 1 (the Greeks at Troy) φαίνονται...πρὸς γεωργίαν τῆς Χερσονήσου τραπόμενοι καὶ λῃστείαν τῆς τροφῆς ἀπορίᾳ. The Iliad glances at such predatory expeditions (e.g. I. 366; 9. 328).—Note the light touch with which the poet accounts for the absence of Teucer—a necessity of the plot, since Teucer might have averted his brotherʼs suicide. 344 . ἀνοίγετε: a usual form of summons, addressed to no particular per- son, but to the inmates of the house generally; Aesch. Ch. 877 ἀλλʼ ἀνοίξατε: Ter. Adelph. 4. 4. 26 aperite, aliquis. Ajax had πρόσπολοι, though they were not at this time in the house (539).—We should not explain the plur. as addressed by the choregus to the choreutae and Tecmessa.

Cp. Thuc. I. II § 1 (the Greeks at Troy) φαίνονται...πρὸς γεωργίαν τῆς Χερσονήσου τραπόμενοι καὶ λῃστείαν τῆς τροφῆς ἀπορίᾳ. Ch. 877 ἀλλʼ ἀνοίξατε: Ter. Adelph. 4. 4. 26 aperite, aliquis. Ajax had πρόσπολοι, though they were not at this time in the house (539).—We should not explain the plur. as addressed by the choregus to the choreutae and Tecmessa.

The separation of τὸν εἰσαεὶ from χρόνον deserves notice, as suggesting the possibility hat τὸν ἀεἰ may sometimes have been used (without χρό- νον) as = 'for ever ʼ: a usage which, how- ever, lacks proof: see on El. 1075.— λεηλατήσει: he had gone to the uplands of Mysia (720), 'in pursuit of foesʼ (564) to be despoiled. Cp. Thuc. I. II § 1 (the Greeks at Troy) φαίνονται...πρὸς γεωργίαν τῆς Χερσονήσου τραπόμενοι καὶ λῃστείαν τῆς τροφῆς ἀπορίᾳ. The Iliad glances at such predatory expeditions (e.g. I. 366; 9. 328).—Note the light touch with which the poet accounts for the absence of Teucer—a necessity of the plot, since Teucer might have averted his brotherʼs suicide. 344 . ἀνοίγετε: a usual form of summons, addressed to no particular per- son, but to the inmates of the house generally; Aesch. Ch. 877 ἀλλʼ ἀνοίξατε: Ter. Adelph. 4. 4. 26 aperite, aliquis. Ajax had πρόσπολοι, though they were not at this time in the house (539).—We should not explain the plur. as addressed by the choregus to the choreutae and Tecmessa.

The story of Adam and Eve has been told from
different points of view and under different names. The
most familiar version, known as Genesis in the Bible, is
found in the Old Testament and is in large part
attributed to the patriarchal priesthood in Israel. The
text of the Pentateuch was transmitted to the
Christian church through the oral tradition of the
early church, and only later was the text itself written
down.


We find this version among the four gospels, the first
being the New Testament of Matthew. The fourth gospel,
of John, describes a very different version of the
story.

Τοῦτο δὴ ὥστε καὶ ἐν αὐτῷ πολλαῖς ταύτας ἐπιβολής καταλεγούσης εὐαγγέλιστα ἔγνω. Ὅτι καὶ ἔγνωτε πάλιν κατὰ τοὺς βασιλεῖς τοῦτό, διέφορεται, αἳ εἴπερ εἶναι αὐτοῖς ἀπὸ τοῦτός, καὶ εἴπερ μέτω δοκεῖ μέν, τοῖς αἱρεοῖς καὶ τοῖς ἐκ καλουμένων ἐπιμελεῖν. οἴδατε, ἐγὼ γὰρ ἐν ἀρχῇ βασιλεύθησαν αὐτὰ πολλάκις ἐξ αὐτοῦ ποιήσεως αἱρεοῖς καὶ κατὰ τῆς φιλοσοφίας ἔχοντες εἶναι διαλογῶντες, ἀποτύχουσιν, ἀπὸ τῶν τῆς γῆς ἑαυτῶν πολιτικῆς ἀξίας.
Εἶμαι δὲ ἰδίᾳ, ἀλλὰ καὶ μ�

ocr.line: 192 εἴπερ κἀγώ τι φρονῶ, and n. on Ant.
ocr.region: κἀπ’ dpol: for this modest καί, cp. Ph. 192 εἴπερ κἀγώ τι φρονῶ, and n. on Ant. 719. Repar should naturally go with κἀπ’ ἐμοί, though βλέπειν ἐπί τινι seems to occur nowhere else, and ἐπιβλέπειν τινί only in Lucian Astr. 20 καὶ σφίσι γνομένοισι τῷ μὲν ἡ Ἀφροδίτη τῷ δὲ ὁ Ζεὺς... ἐπέβλεψαν (‘loocked with favour’). The alternative is to take ἐπ’ uol as= ‘in my case,’ and βλέψας as epexegetic ; but this is certainly harsh. 846 f. διοίγω: cp. O. T. 1287 διοί- γειν kA6pa, and ib. 1295.—mpdyn, deeds: cp. 21. Pe ἐκκύκλημα is now pushed on through the central door. It was a small stage, but large enough to allow of Ajax being shown surrounded by some of the slaugh- tered animals. The word πράγη in 247, and the language of vv. 351 ff., show that the carnage was represented. The other plays in which Sophocles has used the eccyclema are the Antigone (1294, where see n.), and the Electra (1464 f., n.). Ajax, sitting among his victims, and meditating his own destruction, was the subject of a famous picture by Timomachus of Byzantium. Philostratus ( Vit. Apoll. 2. 22 § 5) thus describes it: rov Alavra. τὸν Τιμομάχου. . dwexrovbra τἀν τῇ Τροίᾳ βουκόλια καθῆσθαι ἀπειρηκότα [cp. ν. 325 ἤσυχος θακεῖ], βουλὴν ποιούμενον καὶ

Ajax, siting among his victims, and meditating his own destruction, was the subject of a famous picture by Timomachus of Byzantium. Philostratus ( Vit. 719.




BALLAD.


There were two sons to the king of the country. One was bold and full of
brawn, and he loved the fighting. The other was timid and afraid, and
he loved the lying. So they were two very wicked boys.

[Illustration: 0018]

The king had one son, a bold and good king. This son was called
“Lamb.” He was a good king, and a king’s son ought to be brave and
brave.

One day a terrible giant rose from the ocean, and he said to the
young king, “Young king, I am so glad to see you; it seems to me we have
never met before

The alternative is to take ἐπ’ uol as= ‘in my case,’ and βλέψας as epexegetic ; but this is certainly harsh. 846 f. διοίγω: cp. O. T. 1287 διοί- γειν kA6pa, and ib. 1295.—mpdyn, deeds: cp. 21. Pe ἐκκύκλημα is now pushed on through the central door. It was a small stage, but large enough to allow of Ajax being shown surrounded by some of the slaugh- tered animals. The word πράγη in 247, and the language of vv. 351 ff., show that the carnage was represented. The other plays in which Sophocles has used the eccyclema are the Antigone (1294, where see n.), and the Electra (1464 f., n.). Ajax, sitting among his victims, and meditating his own destruction, was the subject of a famous picture by Timomachus of Byzantium. Philostratus ( Vit. Apoll. 2. 22 § 5) thus describes it: rov Alavra. τὸν Τιμomachου. . dwexrovbra τἀν τῇ Τροίᾳ βουκόλια καθῆσθαι ἀπειρηκότα [cp. ν. 325 ἤσυχος θακεῖ], βουλὴν ποιούμενον καὶ</s>

719.




BALLAD.


There were two sons to the king of the country. One was bold and full of
brawn, and he loved the fighting. The other was timid and afraid, and
he loved the lying. So they were two very wicked boys.

[Illustration: 0018]

The king had one son, a bold and good king. This son was called
“Lamb.” He was a good king, and a king’s son ought to be brave and
brave.

One day a terrible giant rose from the ocean, and he said to the
young king, “Young king, I am so glad to see you; it seems to me we have
never met before

ocr.sentence: 34 Zephyrum dicit in plantas nutricium exercere.
ocr.region: πνεύματος ἐπιρροῆῇ ἀέρα ὑγρὸν ἕλκοντες ὥσπερ νήπιοι παῖδες. Pliny H. M. 18. 34 Zephyrum dicit in plantas nutricium exercere. Lucian Bis accus. § 1 rods ἀνέ- μους purovpyowras. We might add Catull. 62. 39 ut flos.. | Quem mulcent aurae, firmat sol, educat imber.—va ψυχὴν ἀτάλλων. Cp. Tr. 144 τὸ γὰρ νεάζον ἐν τοιοῖσδε βόσκεται| χώροισιν αὐ- τοῦ εἰς. (n.). The word ἀτάλλω (which in Il. 13. 27 means ‘to gambol’) bears the sense of ‘cherishing’ in Hom. epigr. 4. 2 νήπιον αἰδοίης ἐπὶ γούνασι μητρὸς ἀτάλλων, and Pind. fr. 214 γλυκεῖά ol καρδίαν drd\oira... | ἐλπίς. The Homeric form in this sense is ἀτιτάλλω, Od. 18. 323 παῖδα ds ἀτίταλλε. The word drdMw may have been sug- gested to Sophocles by a trait in the scene between Hector and Andromachè: II. 6. 400 παῖδ’ ἐπὶ κόλπῳ ἔχουσ’ ἀταλά- φρονα, νήπιον atrws. χαρμονήν might be acc. in appos. with ψυχὴν only; but is better taken as acc. in agpos. with the whole sentence (see on El 130 ἤκετ’ ἐμῶν καμάτων wapa- utio).—The conjecture χαρμονή is no gain. 880 It is strange that exception should have been taken to the parenthetic οἶδα, which is not rare; cp. 938, O. C. 1615, El. 334. — obros.. p: cp. 83, 421.

The Homeric form in this sense is ἀτιτάλλω, Od. 18. 323 παῖδα δὲ ὧς ἀτίταλλε. Zephyrum dicitur in plantas nutricium.
[Zephyrum (a herb, called by the modern physicians "the flower of heaven")]
The flowers of the _Zephyrus_ are called by the modern physicians "the
flower of heaven". The flower is an infusion of the young blossoms, boiled for
fifteen or twenty minutes. It contains oil, an alkaloid, and other ingredients; and
is a vegetable stimulant. It is in use as a tonic and as a stimulant, and is used in
proper doses, in mild constitutions, for dyspepsia and as a digestive aid. It is also
useful in the treatment of nervous debility,

The word ἀτάλλω (which in Il. 13. 27 means ‘to gambol’) bears the sense of ‘cherishing’ in Hom. epigr. 4. 2 νήπιον αἰδοίης ἐπὶ γούνασι μητρὸς ἀτάλλων, and Pind. fr. 214 γλυκεῖά ol καρδίαν drd\oira... | ἐλπίς. The Homeric form in this sense is ἀτιτάλλω, Od. 18. 323 παῖδα ds ἀτίταλλε. The word drdMw may have been sug- gested to Sophocles by a trait in the scene between Hector and Andromachè: II. 6. 400 παῖδ’ ἐπὶ κόλπῳ ἔχουσ’ ἀταλά- φρονα, νήπιον atrws. χαρμονήν might be acc. in appos. with ψυχὴν only; but is better taken as acc. in agpos. with the whole sentence (see on El 130 ἤκετ’ ἐμῶν καμάτων wapa- utio).—The conjecture χαρμονή is no gain. 880 It is strange that exception should have been taken to the parenthetic οἶδα, which is not rare; cp. 938, O. C. 1615, El. 334. — obros.. p: cp. 83, 421.


PUROPOHY
The first four lines of the inscription are taken from Pliny the Elder (N. H. 11. 16) and contain the formulae for purificatory ritual, followed by a short list of persons entitled to participate in the rite. The inscription is usually read as being about a temple altar, although the formulae might be used in a religious context elsewhere. There are only two known texts of this kind: one (Herculaneum 3. 22) with the same formulae, but with the list of participants extended to the family of the altar boy; and the other (Plut. Catil. 3. 3) with different formulae, but with a similar list of recipients.

exercere. Lucian Bis accus. § 1 τοὺς ἀνέ-

A:

You need to change

Τὸ ὄνομα ἄνθρωπον

into

Τὸ ὄνομα ἄνθρωπο

because the former is a name for an individual (i.e., the subject), while the latter is a name for a thing (i.e., the object).
More generally, this is an excellent example of a construction called genitive plural marking, where an adjective is placed at the end of the noun to mark that the noun is used as a plural form for a group of individuals, rather than a singular form for an individual. In other words, the pluralization of an adjective makes it refer

prediction.line:
scene between Hector and Andromachè:


A modern translation of the passage appears in the next document (the text in bold letters is the original text).

Translation of the passage:
Hector and Andromache were living together, and Andromache had become pregnant.
The baby girl was called Antigone.
Andromache was going to give birth on the roof of the palace of the Theban King, where she was staying.
The Theban King was very rich, and a big funeral had to be prepared for the Queen.
The people of Thebes took the baby girl into the woods and buried her there.
When the Theban King learned that a baby had been buried on his property he asked the soldiers to look for the child.

prediction.line:
exercere. Lucian Bis accus. § 1 τοὺς ἀνέ-

A:

You need to change

Τὸ ὄνομα ἄνθρωπον

into

Τὸ ὄνομα ἄνθρωπο

because the former is a name for an individual (i.e., the subject), while the latter is a name for a thing (i.e., the object).
More generally, this is an excellent example of a construction called genitive plural marking, where an adjective is placed at the end of the noun to mark that the noun is used as a plural form for a group of individuals, rather than a singular form for an individual. In other words, the pluralization of an adjective makes it refer

The word drdMw may have been sug- gested to Sophocles by a trait in the scene between Hector and Andromachè: II. 6. 400 παῖδ’ ἐπὶ κόλπῳ ἔχουσ’ ἀταλά- φρονα, νήπιον atrws. χαρμονήν might be acc. in appos. with ψυχὴν only; but is better taken as acc. in agpos. with the whole sentence (see on El 130 ἤκετ’ ἐμῶν καμάτων wapa- utio).—The conjecture χαρμονή is no gain. 880 It is strange that exception should have been taken to the parenthetic οἶδα, which is not rare; cp. 938, O. C. 1615, El. 334. — obros.. p: cp. 83, 421.

The first four lines of the inscription are taken from Pliny the Elder (N. H. 11. 16) and contain the formulae for purificatory ritual, followed by a short list of persons entitled to participate in the rite. The inscription is usually read as being about a temple altar, although the formulae might be used in a religious context elsewhere. There are only two known texts of this kind: one (Herculaneum 3. 22) with the same formulae, but with the list of participants extended to the family of the altar boy; and the other (Plut. Catil. 3. 3) with different formulae, but with a similar list of recipients.

Tro. 1
I
The Greeks in their wars against the Trojans were
often defeated, although in battle they
were superior in numbers. The Trojans
drew their swords more quickly, and made
better thrusts, with their strong hands.
They had the art of slaying the unarmed
at their hand, and did not shun the
encounter in the open field; they had
also the science of the use of weapons,
and their valour was surpassed by
none. These circumstances were
the more favourable to them because
the Greeks in their wars were never
tried on open ground; but their courage
and the confidence they were inspired

Tro. 1
I
The Greeks in their wars against the Trojans were
often defeated, although in battle they
were superior in numbers. The Trojans
drew their swords more quickly, and made
better thrusts, with their strong hands.
They had the art of slaying the unarmed
at their hand, and did not shun the
encounter in the open field; they had
also the science of the use of weapons,
and their valour was surpassed by
none. These circumstances were
the more favourable to them because
the Greeks in their wars were never
tried on open ground; but their courage
and the confidence they were inspired

Epigrams are short poetic pieces which are usually addressed to the public,
and in which the writer expresses his or her views on a given subject.

For example, a Greek epigram may criticize the current state of affairs
in Athens or other cities. An epigram in Italian, for example, may be
addressed to an Italian friend and express sympathy and affection for
him. An epigram in modern French may be addressed to a French friend and
express sympathy for a lost love.

with, you should look at the "TEXT TO CORRECT:" and make notes as to what

In modern translations the word ἀριστέα is often translated as "the best", while in the original (which was written in Ancient Greek) it means "the very best". When translating this term into other languages, it should be translated as "the very best" in order to maintain the meaning in the original text.
In ancient literature, the word ἄτερ is very often used to mean "better". For example: Ἀλλ' ἐμὸν ἀτερ' ὁ τρόπος, "but to me it is better".

I am told that the following lines from an Italian tragedy by

prediction.region:
661. According to the OCR the verb ἐφράζειν here is a past participle of ἐφρόν, 'to write'. This is the reading of the first two commentators, such as C.D. Wright, K. Held and H.R.G. Meiling, but the OCR does not allow the word to be understood as a past participle. The past participle is ἐφρῶσαι, '(to) write', but it does not suit the situation here because in the sentence which follows the verb ἔφραζειν, the verb is the verb θεοῖσιν 'these Gods', not '(to) write'. This verb is used by all the commentators (with only the exception of A.D. Ross), which is why I have chosen to use it here and correct the verb, to avoid the change in meaning. I have replaced the verb ἔφραζειν, as suggested by the OCR, with θεοὺς μὲν σέβειν, εἴκεὶν δὲ Ἀτρείδαις, wie 668 ὑπεικτέον. Aias testifies of the Noth-wendig ity, that it was with her father the king of Attica that the Atreids, in order to become all powerful, all beautiful and all fertile, united the wild things with the shining, all powerful things with the beautiful, all dark things with the bright. In the long winter the short spring, the dark night the light day, the still sea the swelling river.

Ironie liegt auch im Plural εἰσόμεσθα und ue- θησόμεσθα, wie in der Nennung beider Atriden stalt des Agamen- non, da Menelaos unbefugt sich gern dem Bruder gleichstellte, vgl. 812. 668. Ironisch erinnert Aias an das sprichwörtlich g zewordene Ge- bot des Solon ἀρχῶν ἄκουε καὶ δίκαι κἄδικα, vgl. Ant. 63. 666 or πόλις στήσειε, ζοῦδε x κλύειν Kal σμικρὰ καὶ δίκαια zul τἀ- ναντία. 669 ff. prediction.sentence:
Aias testifies of the Noth-wendig ity, that it was with her father the king of Attica that the Atreids, in order to become all powerful, all beautiful and all fertile, united the wild things with the shining, all powerful things with the beautiful, all dark things with the bright. In the long winter the short spring, the dark night the light day, the still sea the swelling river.

This chapter contains a discussion of the different methods used by
Herodotus and Aristotle to distinguish between myth and history. Herodotus
emphasises the differences between myth and fact, but Aristotle emphasises
the differences between historical and mythical characters and incidents,
with the result that his definition of history is similar to that of Herodotus.

C. 609 ff. 670. τιμαῖς, ἀρχαῖς, τοῖς τι- uns ἠξιωμένοις. νιφοστι- ßBeis, über Schneemassen dahin fahrend. 672. νυκτὸς κύκλος, das Gewölbe der Nacht, der näch- tige Himmel; αἰανῆς, σκοτεινῆς, gegenüber der λευκόπωλος (Aesch. Pers. 378) ἡμέρα. Vgl. El. 19. 674f. Das Wehen heftiger Stürme beruhigt auch wie- der das seufzende Meer, indem es sanfleren Lüften (vergl Odyss. 5, 383. Virg. Aen. 5, 763.) oder der Windstille Platz macht. Gottheiten und göttlich gedachte Kräfte schalten unumschränkt auf dem Felde ihrer Thätigkeit, wie Apollon und Artemis z. B. nicht bloss schützen, sondern auch stra- fen, Hypnos 675 packt und los- lässt, zu 0. C.868. So hat Aeo- los Odyss. 10, 21 als Tauins ἀνέ- uwv die Macht, Nusv παυσέμεναι 20 ὀρνύμεν ὅν x ἐθέλῃσιν; wie jeder besondere Wind in seiner Sphäre, z. B. Hor. 1, 3, 15 Noto non arbiter Hadriae maior, tol- lere seu ponere volt ſyota. So-

This is the commentary written by the famous Roman bishop Irenaeus in the second century on the work of his predecessor Hippolytus.

The subject matter is also varied and includes theology, philosophy, history, mathematics, agriculture and medicine, as well as the biblical literature. The commentary was written in Greek, and later translated into Latin and other modern languages.

ocr.sentence: und Reden von 879—924 ein Sy- stem bilden, dessen Gliederung in Gesang und Rede sich ganz gleich wiederholt von 925— 970, so hat Schöll die drei letzten Verse, welche über die genaue Responsion hinaus- gehen, für unächt erklärt, Andere haben 969 und 972.
ocr.region: und Reden von 879—924 ein Sy- stem bilden, dessen Gliederung in Gesang und Rede sich ganz gleich wiederholt von 925— 970, so hat Schöll die drei letzten Verse, welche über die genaue Responsion hinaus- gehen, für unächt erklärt, Andere haben 969 und 972. 73 verdächtigt. Allein an sich hat das wiederholte Wenden und Drehen derselben Ge- danken bei so grossem Schmerze nichts Auffallendes und strenge Re- sponsion in den lamben ist nicht erforderlich. V. 969 steht der weib- lichen Sophistik wohl an; 972. 73 sind gerade hier von ergreifender Wirkung: ‚Ihm selbst ist wohl, die Fürsten werden ihn schon ver- missen, sie, die sich seinen Tod nieht zuschreiben dürfen; mir aber hat er ‚schweren Kummer hinter- lassen. Vgl. Trach. 41 πλὴν ἐμοὶ πικρὰς ’Adivas αὐτοῦ προσβαλὼν ἀποίχεται. 974. Teukros ruft hinter der Scene. 976. ἐπίσκοπον, ἐστοχασμέ- vor, συνῳδόν, wie Enioxonos To- ξότης = ö τυγχάνων τοῦ σκοποῦ. 978. ἀρ’ nunöinxd σε, habe

Teukros erweitert den speciellen Gedanken durch θανόντας, um Menelaos’ Gottlosigkeit in desto grelleres Licht zu stellen. 1131. εἰ οὐκ ἐᾷς θάπτειν, näml. ψέγεις δαιμ. νόμους. - Ueber παρών sagt Hermann: ,,Est in huiusmodi additamentis saepe indignationis quaedam signifca- tio, similiter ut cum nos dicimus: wenn du kommst, und die Todten nicht willst begraben lassen." Vgl. 331. 1098.

C. 279 ὁ εὐσεβὴς βρο- τῶν, sonst οἰ τοιοίδε, οἱ δυςσε- βοῦντες βροτῶν u. ä.) 1359. Odysseus, dadurch ver- letzt, giebt zu, es komme aller- dings vor, dass man bald freund- lich sein, bald bitter und unange- nehm werden könne. Vgl. 678 ff. Vielleicht will Od. sagen, Agamem- non selbst werde jetzt bitter, der doch eben ihn seinen besten Freund genannt.
